summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against defendant Tag Seog Lee for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Manhattan, alleges that, from at least 2008 through at least November 2016, Kim and his wife purchased an existing printing business called Grip Smart Printing, Inc. (Grip Smart), which incorporated the business as a tenant on a commercial lease. According to the complaint, as a result of this conduct, Grip Smart was not liable for any ADA or Unruh Act violations. The complaint further alleges that when Kim confronted Grip Smart with the facts, he failed to establish a probability of prevailing on his malicious prosecution claim. In addition, the complaint alleges that Grip Smart did not own or control the parking lot where Williams allegedly encountered barriers to her disability. The court found that Kim had no reasonable cause to proceed with the litigation, and that he had failed to show probable cause to bring and maintain the complaint. In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New York announced criminal charges against Grip Smart. The SEC also announced civil injunctions against Kim and Grip Smart, as well as a temporary restraining order against Kim from further violations of the federal securities laws. In its order, the court also ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties equal to the amount of their profits.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's findings, the defendants consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) of Securities Act of 1933, and ordering them to pay civil penalties of $18,172.50 each. The settlement is subject to court approval.  In a separate administrative proceeding, the SEC also issued an order suspending Grip Smart from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney.  On January 29, 2018, the Honorable Dalila Corrales granted the SEC’s motion for summary judgment against Kim. On February 21, 2017, Judge Richard E. Ricchiute of the SEC issued a preliminary injunction against Kim, ordering him to comply with the court order. On May 19, 2017 the court granted a request for a temporary injunction against the issuance of a civil injunctive relief order, ordering Kim to surrender his passport and to pay a $1,500 civil penalty. The order also ordered Kim to pay an $80,000 civil penalty, which was deemed satisfied by the court finding that Kim lacked sufficient cause to
